reviewText: this dvd is phenomenal I bought it because of the price and the fact that it covers so many different grooves.  When I opened it up and put it in my dvd I was amazed at the instruction and the manner in which tommy igoe presented the material it was almost like he was in the room with you.  He expertly covers rock grooves, r and b, hip hop, funk, jazz, different latin and world grooves and even improved my bossa nova groove, even new orleans second line drumming.  He goes over the information independently while talking (which is a skill in itself) covers some pitfalls and gives pointers on then plays the grooves with a band at slow and fast tempos.  I am anxiously awaiting any other dvd instructional that tommy igoe comes out with hopefully more grooves and maybe a dvd on fills.  Tommy Igoes instructionals are definitely the best.
summary: great instructional dvd-- too bad only 47 grooves
Title: N/A

reviewText: I hadn't played drums since high school - 40 years ago - and I had never assembled them from scratch.  When I ordered myself a set last November I also ordered Tommy's "Getting Started on Drums".  I was so impressed by the way he took the mystery out of assembling and tuning the drums as well as the starter lessons on the DVD that I decided to get "Grove Essentals" both the book and this DVD.  I was not dissapointed.  Once again his teaching style is friendly, animated (not a dry lecture) and easy to follow.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There are some excellent and detained reviews so I am going to try to avoid repeating them. Here is my own observations based on owning and using DVD for ten years.The value is that I continue to revisit it. My approach was to master the grooves I immediately needed, and I familiarized myself with the others. Going forward I would draw from it when I needed to learn something in a hurry. So this is not necessarily a DVD that requires that you master it all at once. Think of it as a visual encyclopedia of grooves that are there when you need them.This is probably the best drum video on the market because it cross-trains drummers (a rock drummer can pick up some basic jazz grooves, an R&B; drummer can pick up some Latin, etc.) But, more importantly, Igoe shows you how to think deeper than learning a groove from rote. The way he breaks down each groove, discussing the 'connective tissue' that binds the parts of the groove, and how they work in different tempos gets you thinking about the mechanics. He also gets you thinking in the context of the big picture, especially how many grooves are built from parts borrowed from other ones.Another reason why I claim this is the best is it forces those of us who are in a specific genre to think outside of it. I began drumming in 1964 as a rock drummer, then switched to jazz, and not am playing everything from ragtime to commercial jingles and name-that-tune stuff. I doubt that I would have evolved much had I not stumbled onto this video ten years ago. Therein lies the value: this video grows with you.If you are an advanced level drummer, there are still things to be learned from Igoe's lessons, even if it's how to teach others because his approach is one of the other main strengths of the video. If you are at an advanced level you may want to consider getting this as part of a larger set of material by Mr. Igoe, which includes this, version 2.0 and the play-alongs and workbooks. If so check out this set before making a final purchase decision:Tommy Igoe - Groove Essentials 1.0/2.0 Complete: Includes 2 Books, 2 DVDs, and 2 Posters.
summary: Ground zero for chops and versatility
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have this video, and yes it's very helpful. I'm female, and have been playing a Vistalite for a few years (ie, John Bonham's orange kit)...most drummers I know or have seen play only have ONE groove at most, and maybe three fills, but that's another animal.Slight drawbacks: I would have liked a slower intro demo--there's one with snare drum rudaments, and he starts out so slowly that literally ANYONE could play where he starts the exercise. Needless to say, it gets fast quick, but that's to be expected.i didn't care for the multiple camera angles, and unnecessary film effects. What should have been done was "screen in a screen" with the foot cam on the small one; the rest showing his hands where you can see what's he's doing.he DOES have a GREAT feel, and he's a hottie, which never hurts.I pretty much have all the other drum movies and videos, and my other faves are "Classic rock drum solos with Carmine Appice," "Drumline" (very inspirational drum movie), "the Gene Krupa Story" (with BRILLIANT fakery from Sal Mineo--you still have to be GOOD to fake gene Krupa...), Led Zeppelin's "the Song remains the Same" (look for my amber Vistalite kit in this film), and anything featuring Steve Smith (as in Journey), Neil Peart (as in Rush), Stewart Copeland (the Police) and Santana--who always plays with at least three GREAT drummers live.some guys I know personally if you like drums are Steve Blank on YouTube, and featured on tight-squeezeband.com, and Sean Page, who I once watched fake "2112" and i didn't notice he was faking it--VERY impressive (out of Colorado).
summary: How come I never heard of this guy?
Title: N/A

reviewText: In this DVD Tommy Igoe presents 47 basic grooves that will expand your range and abilities as a drummer regardless of which genre you normally play.The first ten grooves are rock, covering 8th note, 16th note and halftime. Most of these are relatively easy to master and will launch beginning drummers into polished players if they take the time to carefully follow Mr. Igoe's instructions.The grooves become progressively more difficult to play in the subsequent lessons that cover funk, R&B;, jazz and world styles.  Most of the world grooves are based on Latin, but there are some wonderful surprises like the lesson on New Orleans second line drumming.I particularly like the way each groove is introduced, then demonstrated without music, and finally demonstrated at both slow and fast tempo with music.  I also like the fact that Mr. Igoe uses both traditional and match grip, depending on the piece being played, when presenting grooves. This illustrates the fact that both grips are 'legitimate'.There are no fancy fills or solos in this DVD, just basic groove technique, which is exceptionally well presented.  As a side note, Igoe is talking throughout the playing and does so without missing a beat.  That is a skill in itself although it is not what is being taught.Regardless of your skill level or musical genre, this DVD will teach the basics for beginners and break down more complex grooves for advanced and professional drummers, as well as serve as a catalog of grooves for all drummers.The poster that comes with this DVD contains a transcription of each groove.  If you don't read music you can get started by comparing the transcription to what is being played in each lesson, then seek out instruction on reading music.  Or just play and do so with the absolute joy that makes drumming special.
summary: One of the best learning aids
